And I'm Neil. In this episode we’ll be discussing miraculous survivals.

text: Hmm.
Have you ever had a near-death experience, Neil?

text: A near-death experience, meaning a situation where I very nearly died.
A near-death experience, meaning a situation where I very nearly died? Well, I once fell off the side of a mountain, but I was saved by a tree.
speaker: near-death experience

text: That's incredible!
speaker: Dan

text: Why do you ask?

text: Well, I recently heard a story about Alcidez Moreno.
Who's that?

text: He's a window cleaner.
He cleaned the windows on the skyscrapers in New York,
except one day he fell.
Oh my goodness.
speaker: Neil

text: Yes. And what's more is. He survived.

text: Wow.
Wow! How far did he fall?

text: Ah, well, all will be revealed after this week's question.
According to the BBC,
what chance of survival does a human have
when falling to the ground from around three stories?
And by stories, you mean the entire floor of a building,
including all its rooms?
Well, I think it's got to be B, 50%.
Well, we'll find out if you're right or not later. So, do you want to hear the story?
speaker: Dan

text: So, do you want to hear the story?
Of course!

text: Well, on the 7th of December,
Ecuadorians, Alcidez Moreno and his brother, Edgar,
went up to the top of the solo tower in New York
to clean the windows like they did every day.
And how tall is that building?
speaker: Neil

text: It's 47 stories.
And how did they usually clean it?
speaker: Neil

text: Well, they used a scaffold,
which is a structure of interconnected pipes and boards
that creates a frame or shape.
Ah, so in this case, there was a platform
which was attached by cables or large metal ropes
and hung over the edge of the building
and which the window cleaners could raise and lower.
Exactly.
Exactly. So, as usual they filled up their buckets and climbed on to the scaffold.
speaker: scaffold

text: and climbed onto the scaffold.
And, well, unfortunately, the cables were loose
and the scaffold fell from the building.
Both brothers fell 47 stories.
That's terrible.
That's terrible! What happened next?

text: I'll let Joe Fidgin,
I’ll let Jo Fidgen, presenter of the BBC show Outlook, explain

text: explain.
When firefighters arrived on the scene,
they found a crowd of distraught onlookers
pointing towards an alleyway.
Edgar had landed on a fence and couldn't be helped.
But our cedars was found crouching
in a pile of twisted metal,
still clutching the controls of the scaffold.
He was breathing, even trying to stand up.
So, firefighters arrived to find a group of distraught,
which means extremely worried and upset people,
showing them where the two men had come down.
Yes, and though, unfortunately, Edgar didn't survive,
Alcides was found clutching
or holding extremely tightly
to the controls of the scaffold.
Did I hear correctly that he was trying to stand up? Did he escape the accident unscathed?

text: Did he escape the accident unscathed?
Unscathed means without any injury at all.
And…

text: He fell into a coma for three weeks
and he needed 24 pints of blood.
I'm speechless.
I'm speechless. I don't understand how he lived.

text: You aren't the only one.
Listen to what Dr. Philip Barry
from New York Presbyterian Hospital said
about the whole incident.
I don't know what adjective you'd care to use on precedented, extraordinary.
If you are a believer in miracles, this would be one.
Wow, so he can't explain it either.
He said it was unprecedented,
which means never happened or done before.
Yes, and he also said that it was a miracle,
which is an unexplainable positive outcome
to a bad situation
that people say was the intervention of a god.
I guess we'll never know.
I guess we'll never know. But one thing I can know is the answer to this week's question.

text: Ah, yes. I asked you,
what chance of survival does a human have

text: Shall we take a look at the vocabulary then?
First, we had a near-death experience,
which is an experience where a person very nearly
or could easily have died.
Have you ever had one, Dan?
When I was 14, I fell out of a canoe into a river
and got stuck between the boat and a rock
with my head underwater.
I thought it was the end,
but some people pulled me out.
Then we had scaffold.
A scaffold is a structure of interconnected pipes
and boards that creates a frame or shape.
Name a place that you might see scaffolding near.
They are usually put up around houses
when builders are working on the roof.
Then we had clutching.
If you clutch something, it means you hold it extremely tightly.
There's a well-known idiom that uses this word.
Sam, familiar, Dan?
Ah, you're clutching at straws, Neil,
which means you're trying to find a reason or hope to succeed
when it's extremely unlikely.
What was after that?
After that, we had unscathed.
If you are unscathed, you are un-injured.
We often talk about escaping something unscathed.
Have you ever escaped an accident unscathed?
Well, when I was six, I fell through a hole
that some builders had made while doing renovation.
I hit the ground in the garage,
but somehow I escaped unscathed.
Maybe I bounced?
Then we heard unprecedented.
If something is unprecedented,
it has never happened all being done before.
Can you think of an example, Neil?
Well, Neil Armstrong, walking on the moon
was unprecedented in 1969.
And finally, we had miracle.
A miracle is an unexplainable positive outcome
to a bad situation that people say
was the intervention of a god.
The adjective is miraculous.
Do you believe in miracles, Dan?
speaker: miracles

text: Well, I've never seen or experienced one,
but when you hear a story like this,
it's difficult not to.
